A Pakistani man who was passed over for a job in favour of an Indian man has been awarded almost £25,000 in compensation for racial discrimination.

Mohammed Sharief, 43, had been chosen as the best candidate for an adviser's post within Derby city council's equality unit.

But just as he was about to be offered the job the council's then deputy leader, Mark Young, stepped in.

An employment tribunal panel said Mr Young had been "enraged" by the initial choice of candidate.

He was angry at not being consulted on the first interviews and felt the process was flawed.

The panel said he was intent on satisfying the city's ethnic minority mix in the unit, which already had a Pakistani on its staff.

Mr Sharief said his failure to get the job had affected his career and his standing in the community.

"When it became public, it became very hard for me to function in Derby."

He added: "People were always asking me why I didn't get the job.

"I only found out after I served some legal papers on the tribunal that I had been about to be offered it.

"As I understand it now, the assistant chief executive was on the verge of ringing me up when Mr Young stopped her.

"It was clearly political interference on his part. He had not made any promises that anybody was aware of, and for him to cite that was wrong."

Giving evidence to the tribunal, Mr Young insisted that he had only stepped in because of a promise he had made to Derby's ethnic communities.

He said he had assured local Pakistani, Indian and Afro-Caribbean leaders that independent observers would witness all interviews for key posts.

But he admitted he failed to inform council officers or members about this pledge.

He added: "With hindsight, there should have been more communication."

A spokesman for the council said that it believed that Mr Young had been "acting in good faith and had been attempting to broaden and strengthen the recruitment process".

The tribunal ruled that by scrapping its initial process the authority racially discrim inated against a trio of Pakistani candidates.

Mr Sharief, of Derby, was awarded £19,815 for loss of earnings and £5,000 for injury to his feelings.

The other unsuccessful candidates, Mohammed Ayub, of Derby, and Mahoof Rashid, of Rotherham, received compensation of £5,000 and £2,000 respectively.

Solicitor Kevin McFadden, who represented all three men, said: "Race discrimination is not always obvious, and takes many subtle forms.

"More than sending out a message to other local authorities, I hope that the council learns a salutary lesson from this case."

Mr Young stood down as deputy leader in May this year and now works for the Manufacturing, Science and Finance union.
